morning.content: God, I offer myself to Thee - to build with me and to do with me as Thou wilt. Relieve me of the bondage of self, that I may better do Thy will. Take away my difficulties, that victory over them may bear witness to those I would help of Thy Power, Thy Love, and Thy Way of life. May I do Thy will always!
morning.source: Alcoholics Anonymous Big Book, Third Step Prayer

morning.content: When I am disturbed, it is because I find some person, place, thing, or situation – some fact of my life – unacceptable to me, and I can find no serenity until I accept that person, place, thing, or situation as being exactly the way it is supposed to be at this moment.
God, grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, the courage to change the things I can, and the wisdom to know the difference.
First of all, we had to quit playing God. It didn't work.
Resentment is the 'number one' offender. It destroys more alcoholics than anything else.
We admitted we were powerless over alcohol — that our lives had become unmanageable.
Came to believe that a Power greater than ourselves could restore us to sanity.
Made a decision to turn our will and our lives over to the care of God as we understood Him.
Made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves.
Admitted to God, to ourselves, and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs.
Were entirely ready to have God remove all these defects of character.
Humbly asked Him to remove our shortcomings.
Made a list of all persons we had harmed, and became willing to make amends to them all.
Made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others.
Continued to take personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted it.
Sought through prayer and meditation to improve our conscious contact with God as we understood Him, praying only for knowledge of His will for us and the power to carry that out.
Having had a spiritual awakening as the result of these steps, we tried to carry this message to alcoholics, and to practice these principles in all our affairs.

We are not fighting to make liquor illegal. We are not telling anyone else what to do about drinking. We are just sharing our experience of what happened to us, how we got this disease, and how we are recovering from it. We find it helps us to talk to other alcoholics, and we hope our story helps you.
Our primary purpose is to stay sober and help other alcoholics to achieve sobriety.
One day at a time. Just for today, I will not drink.
Easy does it. Don't make things harder than they are. Just do what's in front of you.
First things first. Sobriety comes before everything else.
Let go and let God. Stop trying to control everything and place your trust in a Higher Power.
This too shall pass. No feeling, positive or negative, is permanent.
Progress, not perfection. Recovery is a journey, not a destination.
H.A.L.T. - Don't get too Hungry, Angry, Lonely, or Tired.
Faith without works is dead. Beliefs must be followed by actions.
It works if you work it, so work it, you're worth it!

My Creator, I am now willing that you should have all of me, good and bad. I pray that you now remove from me every single defect of character which stands in the way of my usefulness to you and my fellows. Grant me strength, as I go out from here, to do your bidding. Amen.
morning.source: Alcoholics Anonymous Big Book, Seventh Step Prayer

evening.content: God, I thank you for this day. I know I have not been perfect, but I believe that because of you I am able to be a better person. Help me to be even better tomorrow and forgive me for my imperfections today.

We reviewed our day. Were we resentful, selfish, dishonest or afraid? Do we owe an apology? Have we kept something to ourselves which should be discussed with another person at once? Were we kind and loving toward all? What could we have done better? Were we thinking of ourselves most of the time? Or were we thinking of what we could do for others, of what we could pack into the stream of life?
After making our review we ask God's forgiveness and inquire what corrective measures should be taken.

evening.prompt: Do I need to apologize to anyone?
What am I grateful for today?
What could I have done better today?
Was I kind and loving toward all today?
Am I keeping secrets that should be shared?
Did I do anything I'm ashamed of today?
How can I better serve others tomorrow?
Did I think of myself most of the time today?

evening.content: God, I give this day back to you. Whether I felt useful or not, whether I did what I set out to do or not, I trust that your purpose for me was fulfilled today in ways I may not have expected or intended. Help me to rest in gratitude for all I've been given, to hold my shortcomings with grace, and to wake tomorrow with hope. I surrender myself, my will, and my life to your care.
